message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The relationship between belief and credence
Paper Abstract: Abstract Sometimes epistemologists theorize about belief , a tripartite attitude on which one can believe, withhold belief, or disbelieve a proposition. In other cases, epistemologists theorize about credence , a fine‐grained attitude that represents one's subjective probability or confidence level toward a proposition. How do these two attitudes relate to each other? This article explores the relationship between belief and credence in two categories: descriptive and normative. It then explains the broader significance of the belief‐credence connection and concludes with general lessons from the debate thus far. Video Abstract link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3eOSlPVYxI8&feature=youtu.be
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the results of my web search for "belief epistemology philosophy":

## Overview of Epistemology

Epistemology is the branch of philosophy that examines the nature, origin, and limits of knowledge.(no content)Epistemologists study the concepts of belief, truth, and justification to understand the nature of knowledge.

## Belief in Epistemology

In epistemology, philosophers use the term belief to refer to attitudes about the world which can be either true or false.(no content)Central concepts in epistemology include belief, truth, evidence, and reason.

## Key Epistemological Theories

Justification (also called epistemic justification) is a property of beliefs that fulfill certain norms about what a person should believe. Several major theories address how beliefs are justified:

- Foundationalism – Basic beliefs justify other, non-basic beliefs. Coherentism – Beliefs are justified if they cohere with other beliefs a person holds, each belief is justified if it coheres with the overall system of beliefs.
- Reliabilism – A belief is justified if it is the result of a reliable process.

## The Traditional Analysis of Knowledge

According to the so-called traditional analysis, knowledge has three components: it is a belief that is justified and true. However, in the second half of the 20th century, this view was challenged by a series of thought experiments aiming to show that some justified true beliefs do not amount to knowledge.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

In epistemology, philosophers use the term belief to refer to attitudes about the world which can be either true or false.(no content)Central concepts in epistemology include belief, truth, evidence, and reason.

## Key Epistemological Theories

Justification (also called epistemic justification) is a property of beliefs that fulfill certain norms about what a person should believe. Several major theories address how beliefs are justified:

- Foundationalism – Basic beliefs justify other, non-basic beliefs. Coherentism – Beliefs are justified if they cohere with other beliefs a person holds, each belief is justified if it coheres with the overall system of beliefs.
- Reliabilism – A belief is justified if it is the result of a reliable process.

## The Traditional Analysis of Knowledge

According to the so-called traditional analysis, knowledge has three components: it is a belief that is justified and true. However, in the second half of the 20th century, this view was challenged by a series of thought experiments aiming to show that some justified true beliefs do not amount to knowledge.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of epistemology in philosophy:

## What is Epistemology?

Epistemology is the philosophical study of knowledge and related concepts, such as justification.(no content)Also called theory of knowledge, it examines the nature and types of knowledge.(no content)Epistemology is one of the major branches of philosophy, alongside ethics, logic, and metaphysics.

## Core Questions and Topics

Epistemology investigates the sources of knowledge, like perception, inference, and testimony, to understand how knowledge is created, and addresses what people can and cannot know.(no content)Epistemologists study the concepts of belief, truth, and justification to understand the nature of knowledge, and investigate sources of justification, such as perception, introspection, memory, reason, and testimony.

## Major Schools of Thought

Empiricists hold that all knowledge comes from sense experience, whereas rationalists believe that some knowledge does not depend on it.(no content)The school of skepticism questions the human ability to attain knowledge, while fallibilism says that knowledge is never certain.

## Specialized Areas

Separate branches of epistemology focus on knowledge in specific fields, like scientific, mathematical, moral, and religious knowledge.(no content)Naturalized epistemology relies on empirical methods and discoveries, formal epistemology uses formal tools from logic, social epistemology investigates the communal aspect of knowledge, and historical epistemology examines its historical conditions.

Web search results for query: "subjective probability"

Links: [{"title":"Subjective probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Subjective_probability&redirect=no"},{"title":"Probability interpretations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability_interpretations"},{"title":"Bayesian probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_probability"},{"title":"Subjective logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_logic"},{"title":"Subjective expected utility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_expected_utility"},{"title":"Bruno de Finetti - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_de_Finetti"},{"title":"Dutch book theorems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_book_theorems"},{"title":"Expected utility hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_utility_hypothesis"},{"title":"List of publications in statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_publications_in_statistics"}]

## Subjective Probability

Subjective probability is the notion of probability regarded as a measure of the 'rational degree of belief' of the individual assessing the uncertainty of a particular situation. Also called epistemic or Bayesian probability, it is sometimes called credence, as opposed to the term chance for a propensity probability.

### Key Characteristics

Subjective probability is an interpretation of the concept of probability in which probability is interpreted as reasonable expectation representing a state of knowledge or as quantification of a personal belief.(no content)When people say that "it will probably rain," they typically do not mean that the outcome is a random factor, but rather such statements are better understood as qualifying their expectation with a degree of confidence.

### Rational Constraints

Bayesians point to the work of Ramsey and de Finetti as proving that subjective beliefs must follow the laws of probability if they are to be coherent (rational). Importantly, while degrees of belief are subject to some rational constraints, these constraints usually do not determine a unique value—rational people may differ somewhat in their degrees of belief, even if they all have the same information.

### Historical Development

Bruno de Finetti was an Italian probabilist statistician noted for the "operational subjective" conception of probability.(no content)De Finetti developed his ideas on subjective probability in the 1920s independently of Frank P. Ramsey.

Web search results for query: "proposition logic philosophy"

Links: [{"title":"Propositional logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_logic"},{"title":"Proposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proposition"},{"title":"Philosophy of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_logic"},{"title":"Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic"},{"title":"Law of thought - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_thought"},{"title":"Square of opposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_of_opposition"},{"title":"Philosophical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophical_logic"},{"title":"Propositional formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_formula"},{"title":"Logical possibility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_possibility"},{"title":"History of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of propositional logic in philosophy:

## Definition and Scope

Propositional logic deals with statements, which are defined as declarative sentences having truth value.(no content)It deals with propositions (which can be true or false) and relations between propositions, including the construction of arguments based on them.

## Key Concepts

Compound propositions are formed by connecting propositions by logical connectives representing the truth functions of conjunction, disjunction, implication, biconditional, and negation.(no content)Propositional logic is typically studied with a formal language, in which propositions are represented by letters, which are called propositional variables. These are then used, together with symbols for connectives, to make propositional formulas. Because of this, the propositional variables are called atomic formulas of a formal propositional language.

## Historical Development

Although propositional logic had been hinted by earlier philosophers, Chrysippus is often credited with development of a deductive system for propositional logic as his main achievement in the 3rd century BC which was expanded by his successor Stoics.(no content)Symbolic logic, which would come to be important to refine propositional logic, was first developed by the 17th/18th-century mathematician Gottfried Leibniz.

## Philosophical Questions

Philosophers disagree about what exactly a proposition is, as well as about which sentential connectives in natural languages should be counted as logical connectives.(no content)Linguistics and philosophy of language typically understand propositions as the meanings of declarative sentences.

Links: [{"title":"Credence (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credence_(statistics)"},{"title":"Bayesian epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_epistemology"},{"title":"Probability interpretations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability_interpretations"},{"title":"Bayesian probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_probability"},{"title":"Uniqueness thesis (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniqueness_Thesis_(Epistemology)"},{"title":"Propensity probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propensities"},{"title":"Certainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Certain"},{"title":"Uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_bracket_notation"},{"title":"Probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability"},{"title":"Talk:Doomsday argument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Doomsday_argument"}]

Here's what the search results reveal about credence and subjective probability:

## Definition and Connection

Credence or degree of belief is a statistical term that expresses how much a person believes that a proposition is true.(no content)Epistemic or subjective probability is sometimes called credence, as opposed to the term chance for a propensity probability.(no content)According to the Bayesian interpretation of probability, credences stand for subjective probabilities.

## How Credence is Measured

Credence is a measure of belief strength, expressed as a percentage, and credence values range from 0% to 100%.(no content)These degrees come in values between 0 and 1, where a degree of 1 implies that a claim is completely accepted, a degree of 0 corresponds to full disbelief, and a degree of 0.5 corresponds to suspension of belief.

## Practical Examples

For example, if Alice is fairly certain that she saw Bob at the grocery store on Monday, then she might say, "I believe with 90% credence that Bob was at the grocery store on Monday."(no content)A reasonable person will believe with close to 50% credence that a fair coin will land on heads the next time it is flipped.

## Relationship to Rationality

Credence is closely related to odds, and a person's level of credence is directly related to the odds at which they will place a bet.(no content)Bayesians point to the work of Ramsey and de Finetti as proving that subjective beliefs must follow the laws of probability if they are to be coherent (rational).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence explaining why it matters)

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "The relationship between belief and credence". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Paper Classification & Analysis

**Paper Type:** Survey - This paper reviews and explores the relationship between belief and credence, concluding with lessons from epistemological debate rather than proposing novel methodology.

**Key Entities Identified & Extracted:**

| Entity | Type | Relation | Relevance |
|--------|------|----------|-----------|
| Belief | Concept | uses | Core epistemological concept representing a tripartite attitude examined throughout the paper |
| Credence (statistics) | Concept | uses | Fine-grained epistemic attitude of subjective probability that the paper analyzes and relates to belief |
| Subjective probability | Concept | uses | Mathematical foundation of credence as a measure of rational degree of belief |
| Epistemology | Concept | uses | The philosophical discipline within which the belief-credence relationship is analyzed |
| Proposition | Concept | uses | Objects toward which beliefs and credences are directed in epistemological analysis |

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed successfully with 5 triples properly formatted and Wikipedia URLs verified.

The JSON output has been saved to `triples_output.json` with all required fields properly populated.

Sources:
- [Belief - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief)
- [Credence (statistics) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credence_(statistics))
- [Subjective probability - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_probability)
- [Epistemology - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology)
- [Proposition - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proposition)
